title: 112_s1129
content: The "Grazing Improvement Act of 2011" amends the terms of grazing permits and leases by extending the duration from 10 years to 20 years. It also includes provisions for the renewal, transfer, and reissuance of grazing permits and leases under Title IV of the Federal Land Policy and Management Act of 1976. The "Grazing Improvement Act of 2011" extends the duration of grazing permits and leases from 10 to 20 years. It defines terms like environmental analysis and Secretary concerned, and mandates the renewal or reissuance of expired permits under specific sections of the law. The "Grazing Improvement Act of 2011" extends the duration of grazing permits and leases from 10 to 20 years. It mandates that terms and conditions of expired permits continue until renewed, permits can be cancelled, suspended, or modified, and renewal must comply with applicable laws, including the National Environmental Policy Act of 1969. The renewal, reissuance, or transfer of a grazing permit or lease by the Secretary concerned is exempt from environmental analysis if it continues current grazing management. Minor modifications also qualify for exemption if monitoring shows progress towards meeting objectives in the land management plan. The Secretary concerned has the discretion to prioritize and determine the timing for completing environmental analyses for grazing allotments, permits, or leases based on their environmental significance and available funding. This decision must align with the land and resource management plan and the policy of the Department of the Interior or Agriculture regarding extraordinary circumstances. The Secretary can prioritize environmental analyses for grazing allotments, permits, or leases based on their significance and funding availability. This does not apply to renewals or transfers categorically excluded under subsection (e). SEC. 4. APPLICABILITY OF ADMINISTRATIVE PROCEDURE ACT TO GRAZING APPEALS. The Forest and Rangeland Renewable Resources Planning Act of 1974 and the Federal Land Policy and Management Act of 1976 are amended to include provisions regarding the applicability of the Administrative Procedure Act to grazing permit decisions. The Forest and Rangeland Renewable Resources Planning Act of 1974 and the Federal Land Policy and Management Act of 1976 are amended to include provisions for grazing permit decisions to fall under the jurisdiction of the Department of the Interior. Appeals by grazing permittees must adhere to the Administrative Procedure Act, with a 30-day deadline for filing appeals. Suspensions of decisions by the Secretary concerned are in place until the appeal is resolved, unless determined otherwise. The Secretary concerned may not suspend a decision on grazing permits in case of an emergency. Applicants granted grazing use in the previous year can continue at the authorized level until the appeal is resolved.
